segments.question: I see. Okay. And what is the first thing that you noticed that was different?
segments.answer: The food. We didn't get much food. It was rationed. And the ruthlessness of the German occupiers. They'd just beat people up, beat kids up, beat grownups up and got them to work or picked them up in the street and took them to work.

segments.question: So in other words, I get the sense that there's really no fighting that actually happened; that there was no fight that was put up in your area. They just ran in.

segments.answer: Oh, yes. The Wehrmacht came in, the SS right after that. You know, I didn't know who was’ an SS manis, but I did know what an Wehrmacht is.

segments.question: Was that across the board for everybody or was this particular targeted to the Jews?
segments.answer: That, I don't know. I would imagine it was across the board.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don't know.

segments.answer: They just didn't know. And so, like, myself, I was able to go anywhere even where the soldiers were and, you know, it was okay. I was afraid, but I did go. segments.question: Well, when you would go, you know, I take it out of, like, a child's curiosity to see what was’ what are some of the things you saw?

segments.answer: No. They just you know, kids are kids everywhere. They tried to get out of line.

segments.answer: You were called to a square. Everybody had to appear. And they picked out I don't know how they went about picking out picking out people. I have no idea. And but they did. segments.answer: There was violence. There was a German population that they moved in and they used to beat up the Jewish kids or the Jewish people.

segments.answer: Civilians and occasionally they had the SS going through there. And, you know, they picked up people. They you know, I cannot explain they used to beat them up, and sometimes they picked them up and killed them.

segments.question: Did you see corpses in the streets?
segments.answer: Not at the time that I was in the ghetto. I saw corpses from starvation. Occasionally, yes, I did see, but not many.

segments.answer: Two Polish Jewish soldiers; brought them in because they called the German soldier and I don't know what happened. And they brought them in. segments.answer: Yes. But I saw within the town. And they did something, and I don't know what they did. And they just shot them.

segments.answer: Hm, yeah. It was a bad time.

segments.answer: No, not really. You know, I got hit a couple times across my back. But that's about it, you know.

segments.answer: -- the U.S. military, the Third Army moved up and took over Weimar and they came in to us.

segments.answer: The Americans liberated us in Buchenwald, yes. But it took -- it's a longer story than that because they used to take out people out of the prison camp, either kill them or get rid of them. I don't know what they did with them.

segments.question: When you're talking about they took them out, who took them out?
segments.answer: The Germans took them out.

segments.question: That's what I thought. Okay. So the Germans --
segments.answer: Before the U.S. came, the U.S. Army.

segments.question: Before they came.
segments.answer: Before they came.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: They took out, in fact, one of them, a person, my hometown, their father they took out. But he was . For some reason or another, they kept the kids intact. The prisoners themselves were political prisoners, a lot of them. They made sure that these kids, these Jewish kids, that they kept in barracks 66, 64, 65 got maintained.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: They took, they sort of took care of them. I found out later. I didn't know that. And so the U.S. Army moved in and here we were.

segments.question: What was that like? My God, three, almost three years then that you had been in the camp system, that you had been under such conditions. And all of a sudden, these GIs appear.
segments.answer: The Gls, yeah. Let me just --

segments.question: We can stop. Hang on. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 69
segments.answer: Okay. (Pause)

segments.question: Okay. They came in.
segments.answer: They came in. There were mostly Jewish kids. And I understand, from what I heard and what I saw, was some non-Jewish kids too among the Jewish kids.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And they took over. They fed us. Put us, really, back together to help and the really, whoever with tuberculosis, with TB --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- was sent to Switzerland, to Sweden, to Germany into the mountains. And they took a group of kids that the French government okayed it and they took us to France.

segments.question: So you went to France?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: With your brother?
segments.answer: One brother and -- there was about three sets of brothers the same way.

segments.question: Who also went to France.
segments.answer: . Yes.

segments.question: How did you get there?
segments.answer: They took us by train.

segments.question: They took you by train.
segments.answer: Yeah. When the U.S. Army moved in, they had a rabbi that came over and took the Jewish kids. And some of them were non-Jewish. And they had a segment of the kids Interview with Jacques Ribons 70 that they sent to France, they sent them to Switzerland, to England. You know, whichever country took them in.

segments.question: Okay. So you end up in France.
segments.answer: I end up in France.

segments.question: Before we go to France, what was in France, tell me, when you were in Buchenwald and right before the Americans come, what happened with the German guards and the German authorities?
segments.answer: Well, the German authority were -- for instance, you know, I was sick. I came out of the hospital and I was laying there on one of the bunks, so to speak, like a shelf.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And there was a window and glass and I used to, I watched the main road. All ofa sudden I saw tanks moving up in that glass. It was like a mirror reflection in the glass. And I knew the U.S. Army is moving in. So when they came in, they took the kids. And the rabbis, the priests, they gave them, you know --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- food. They gave them medicine. And some of them had to be hospitalized and they brought us back sort of together.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And, you know, back to health, so to speak. And they sorted out kids to go to France, it had to do with their health also, to England, and to some other countries, you know, that they -- I don't know all the countries that the kids went to, so.

segments.question: Yes. Interview with Jacques Ribons 71
segments.answer: But they spread them out. Each country took in so many kids, you know.

segments.question: But I was backing up to ask you what had happened to all of the German guards. Did they disappear? Were they arrested? Did they run away”?
segments.answer: The Germans had jumped off the towers --

segments.question: Pardon?
segments.answer: -- during that because -- the guard towers.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And they started running.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: If the GIs came up on one of them, they killed them, you know.

segments.question: Got it.
segments.answer: They were running away from the prison, period. And I guess, I don't know who they caught, the main commandant was caught by the U.S. Army. The main people that were caught, the same thing. They had sort of a mini revolution within that prison because there were a lot of Germans that worked 1n that prison also that were there for many years.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Germans that were not Nazis.

segments.question: That's right. Political prisoners. There were a lot of political prisoners.
segments.answer: Political prisoners that were put in there.

segments.question: Yeah. And so --
segments.answer: But they're the ones primarily that run that prison. Interview with Jacques Ribons 72

segments.question: Yeah. Did --
segments.answer: Had access to armament. There was a munition factory --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- and an armament factory in one of the prisons down the road. And they had a man over there that worked in that prison, the munition factory. And one of them was Leon Blum.

segments.question: Really? Well, I --
segments.answer: I don't know whether he survived or not.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But he was one of the people that was in that. But prison, the armament.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And the U.S. Air Force bombed it. And after that, I don't know what happened to the people.

segments.question: Yeah. Yeah. So you end up in Paris. I mean, excuse me, in France. Was it Paris or was it somewhere else?
segments.answer: Yeah, they dispersed all the kids.

segments.question: Excuse me?
segments.answer: They dispersed the kids.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Some of them went into ;

segments.question: Yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 73
segments.answer: Others went into a religious home. They had -- they divided them, you know, in different homes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Then they had, I want to say they had homes for the French kids also there. So they put them together.

segments.question: That's right.
segments.answer: Jewish kids that had, you know, that survived the war.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: The French kids. One of my friends -- and the OSE took over. I don't know whether you're familiar with the OSE.

segments.question: Well, tell me about it. What is it?
segments.answer: OSE was an organization that was from, I guess -- a French organization which took care of the kids to make sure they go to school and some of them had trades and they paid for the education.

segments.question: Was it a government organization?
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: Was it a Jewish organization?
segments.answer: It was a Jewish organization.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Primarily Jewish. I don't know whether it was totally Jewish. It was like --

segments.question: How do you spell the acronym?
segments.answer: I don't know. It was initials O-S-E. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 74

segments.question: O-S-E, okay. Okay. OSE. And --
segments.answer: They sent a friend of mine to school. He came to the United States and became a millionaire.

segments.question: Wow. And what about you? When you got off the train, what kind of a place were you --
segments.answer: I went into a Jewish religious situation.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Even though I wasn't religious, I went into that home.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don't know. I don't know what I was thinking. And I started going to school a little bit and then I returned to the United States in 1947.

segments.question: So you were in France for, let's say, almost two years?
segments.answer: Almost.

segments.question: Did you learn --
segments.answer: I would say a year and a half. April, in April, to be specific, April the 11th was my freedom day in Buchenwald.

segments.question: Well, those kind of dates you don't forget.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: April 11th was freedom. And was your brother with you?
segments.answer: My brother was with me and there were other two sets of brothers, one of the brothers of the father that they took out and disappeared.

segments.question: That's right. That's right. So did your brother go with you to France as well? Interview with Jacques Ribons 75
segments.answer: Yes, yes. He was with me all along.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He was with me --

segments.question: Same school, same everything?
segments.answer: Pardon me?

segments.question: He was in the same religious family, then?
segments.answer: Yeah. It wasn't a family. It was a home --

segments.question: It was ahome. Excuse me. Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- for religious kids, I think donated by the Rothschild family --

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: -- you know, for the kids to stay there.

segments.question: Yeah. The Rothschilds, yeah.
segments.answer: And they had Jewish religion, Jewish food, and Jewish upbringing, so to speak, you know. And, like, again, like Elie Wiesel was there also with us.

segments.question: Oh. So is that where you met him?
segments.answer: That's where I met him, right.

segments.question: Okay. Okay. Did you learn French?
segments.answer: Pardon me?

segments.question: Did you learn French?
segments.answer: Oh, yes. I went to French school. You know, it's been a long, long time. I still speak it but I'm a little rusty on it. Interview with Jacques Ribons 76

segments.question: Well, but it's such a huge change, where one month you were a prisoner in a concentration camp and month and a half later you're in a home in France and the following September you go to school.
segments.answer: It wasn't just like that. First of all, I don't know the time --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- you know, the time it took.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: After liberation, again, after a while, we went to Switzerland, went off. A Jewish serviceman, who was a rabbi, he saw to it that the French government, they picked out certain kids that were, I guess, a little healthier then a lot of them --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- and, you know, designated for France. We were there for several months before we left for France.

segments.question: Oh, really.
segments.answer: Yeah. I don't know about several months. Maybe a couple months. Three months.

segments.question: Yeah. But you were there for a while.
segments.answer: Just for a while.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Again, the time wasn't important to me then.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: So then they picked kids to go, the sick kids, some of them went to Sweden.

segments.question: Yes. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 77
segments.answer: Some of them went to Switzerland that had TB so, you know, to get -- to recuperate. Myself and my brother and a whole bunch of other kids, I don't know how many it was, we were designated to go to France. And when we came to France, we had doctors --

segments.question: Yeah?
segments.answer: -- that checked us over. And they placed us in sort of a vacation home in the country, which was also one of the Rothschilds' homes.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Excuse me. And so we were there for a while. The time element, I just don't, couldn't tell you.

segments.question: Okay. That's okay.
segments.answer: Then we went back to Versailles. We went to Versailles, rather, back -- the first time. We went to Versailles. And then they sent us to school, to public school. Some of them had families, they found families in the U.S. Some of them found each other. We had French kids also for a while but very few of them, what we did have.

segments.question: Well, in 1945 -- you say your birthday is in August. So in 1945 you turned 18 years old, right?
segments.answer: Actually, I -- the truth of the matter, I was born in October.

segments.question: Excuse me. You born in October.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. So it's October --
segments.answer: The reason for August is this. I came to this country. The guy, the guy who had my certificate that I had from the U.S. Army from, you know, from, Germany -- Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 78

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- read it as August.

segments.question: Ah, I see.
segments.answer: Because it's very similar. And he misread it.

segments.question: Okay. So you --
segments.answer: So I just let it go. I didn't want to change it. I changed the name but I didn't change the date. It was a couple months. It didn't matter.

segments.question: Okay. Okay. So officially you were born --
segments.answer: October.

segments.question: -- August 15th but in reality you were born October 15th?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Okay. 1927.
segments.answer: So I left it, you know, for, you know, August.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah, August. I go by August.

segments.question: So here's my question. By August 15th, 1945, you are free.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And -- but for one --
segments.answer: No, in April. We were freed in April.

segments.question: Correct. Correct. But what I want to say is, at age 18, one-third of your life had been spent in, one could say, absolute fear from the time the war started, when you were 12, and it started just a -- you know, just before your 12th birthday -- Interview with Jacques Ribons 79
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: -- on September Ist. And I wonder what kind of a person you were at age 18, you know, having gone through all that. How would you describe yourself at the time?
segments.answer: You know, I had here an uncle. And also an aunt.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I didn't know much about the aunt.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But my uncle, when he found me in the newspaper, he found the name in the newspaper --

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: -- wrote me a letter. He couldn't write nothing else but Yiddish.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So he wrote me this letter and asked who my family 1s.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: It turned out that I was his sister's kids, me and my brother.

segments.question: So, in other words, your mother's brother?
segments.answer: My mother's brother was in the U.S.

segments.question: Oh, my goodness. Had you known about him before?
segments.answer: No. I knew she has a brother but I didn't know where and what. I didn't know even how to go about it anyhow.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: There was -- he was illiterate. Excuse me just a minute. I need to cough. Interview with Jacques Ribons 80

segments.question: Sure. (Pause)
segments.answer: Thank you.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Are you on again?

segments.question: I'm on. I'm here.
segments.answer: Yeah. Okay. So he, he was -- I didn't know where he was but they told me . He was illiterate. Only he knew how to write in Yiddish.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He came and found a job as a weaver. A weaver is people that make cloth

segments.question: That's right, uh-huh.
segments.answer: And he worked for Botany 500, which is a famous company.

segments.question: What kind of company?
segments.answer: Botany 500.

segments.question: Botany 500?
segments.answer: Yes. They went out of business now.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Because of the innovation of the mechanical, you know, that they have. The factories, you know, they run it on electricity but -- so he worked for them for many, many years because at home he was trained as a weaver, weaving fabrics.

segments.question: I see. Interview with Jacques Ribons 81
segments.answer: Excuse me.

segments.question: That's okay. Do you want to take a pause?
segments.answer: Thank you. Yes.

segments.question: Okay. We'll pause a little bit.
segments.answer: Thank you.

segments.question: Okay. So we're continuing. And you're saying your uncle was a weaver here for many years in the United States. And he found you through a newspaper.
He spoke to you and asked if you were so and so's son and it turns out that he was your mother's brother.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: So what happened after that?
segments.answer: Well, he didn't have money. He was a very poor man but had a soul. But he -- I don't know where he went. I understand he went to the people that make matzo. And they supposedly had signed papers for me and my brother. And the thing was, you know, we communicated at that time in Yiddish.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Which I can still, I guess I can still write. But I don't use it. But at any rate, he -- I -- he sent me papers, immigration papers.

segments.question: Yes. Interview with Jacques Ribons 82
segments.answer: The matzo company signed that I would be important in the government, which is a normal thing for immigrants.

segments.question: So they guaranteed you. The matzo company gave their guarantee.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: They were like your official sponsors.
segments.answer: They were official sponsor. So I got the papers and of course the people in France --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- made sure that everything goes smooth. We went to the American consulate, x-ray taken, so on and so forth. And we got immigration papers. For whatever reason, they said that we have to hurry up and be in Sweden by such and such a date --

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: -- getting on a ship to go to the U.S. So we got on a train and we went to Sweden, a whole bunch of kids.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don't know how many.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They put us on the ship, a Swedish ship.

segments.question: Do you remember the name of 1t?
segments.answer: You know something? It kind of -- yes, I do but it slipped my mind.

segments.question: Not right now. That's okay. That's not a problem. So, anyway, they put you on this ship and you're on your way to the United States. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 83
segments.answer: That ship was a troop ship during the war. That I know. In fact, I have probably a picture of it too.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Excuse me.

segments.question: There are a couple of them that were pretty famous but the names slips my mind as well. One of the first ships out of Europe was used for military purposes. Anyway, was it a --
segments.answer: That was a ship ,

segments.question: -- Swedish ship or a U.S. ship?
segments.answer: It was, yeah, made into a troop ship or whatever.

segments.question: Yes, but was it -- belonged to the Americans?
segments.answer: I don't know who it belonged to. It had the Swedish name.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: It was a Swedish ship.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: As far as I know.

segments.question: Okay. Got it.
segments.answer: We got the papers. Put us on the train. And we came to Copenhagen.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We went all through Germany, which was bombed out.

segments.question: Yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 84
segments.answer: We finally got to Copenhagen. And from Copenhagen we went to -- I guess by train. The train. Got on the ship and took us across the waters and wound up in Gothenburg, Sweden.

segments.question: I remember, yes, it's the tip of Sweden. The bottom part, yes.
segments.answer: Yeah. So in Gothenburg, we boarded the ship to the U.S. And I don't know how many days it took. I don't remember. And believe it or not, we wound up in New York City. The ship pulled up to dock. And it docked. And my uncle was supposed to come to getus. Well, he couldn't. We got off the ship. We don't have -- we have just clothes what we had on. We thought, well, when we get to the U.S., we'll buy new clothing.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So we tossed most of the stuff in the ocean. And we got off the ship. My uncle isn't there.

segments.question: What did you do?
segments.answer: That was the good question. The question was what do I do.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But apparently he had enough sense to call one of the Jewish organizations in New York. I can't remember which one. They came and picked us up after a while. And we spent some time there.

segments.question: Where did your uncle live, by the way? What part of the U.S.?
segments.answer: New York City.

segments.question: Your uncle lived in New York but he wasn't able to --
segments.answer: No, no. My uncle lived in Paterson, New Jersey. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 85

segments.question: He lived in Paterson, New Jersey?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So we went there and they gave us -- you know, I smoked so they gave us, they gave me cigarettes. Brought us some clothing, this organization. Was it HIAS?

segments.question: HIAS could very well be it.
segments.answer: Or one of the organizations similar to HIAS. Or HIAS itself. And he came -- tried to pick us up. They couldn't . My aunt had a heart attack and he couldn't come to get me.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: But I didn't know that. Nobody else knew it.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: I'm in New York City with my brother. I have five cents, I swear to you, five cents and I smoked no cigarettes.

segments.question: Oh, my goodness. Oh, my goodness.
segments.answer: Here, I'm in New York City with my brother. I didn't know what to do. So luckily enough, he called this organization. Came, picked us up, kept us for a few days. And they gave -- fed us. Gave us cigarettes to smoke. And my brother smoked. And he finally came to get us. Well, we went to New Jersey. I discovered my uncle is very poor.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: He lived in this apartment in Paterson, New Jersey.

segments.question: Yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 86
segments.answer: And his wife was sick. What can we do. I couldn't stay with him.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So he called another organization in Paterson, New Jersey, which they were absolutely terrific, the people were terrific, and found us an apartment, a room in somebody's house until we, you know -- and put us there. And I went out looking for a job.

segments.question: And you didn't speak any English.
segments.answer: Nope, not a word. Some bad words that I listened to the GIs they used that I found out later what it was.

segments.question: Oh, dear. Oh, dear. So you were in New Jersey and you started looking for work.
segments.answer: For work. And I didn't start school. My brother was young. hired from anybody, you know. We just stayed a while in New Jersey. And somebody came to work that picked him up that lived in Los Banos, California. It was a cotton -- a Jewish guy, who was an American. He owned a cotton farm. And he was going to take him and educate him, you know.

segments.question: Clear across the country.
segments.answer: Clear across the country. And myself, I went to school. Tried to learn English. And of course I met some people and, you know, so on and so forth. And I learned a little at a time and I started going to school, you know. So my brother finally, he got upset about something. He never told me what it was.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And he came back. And I moved, I moved to Los Angeles. I couldn't stay with my uncle -- Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 87

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: -- because he didn't have time. He couldn't do anything for me.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I couldn't do anything for him.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And New Jersey wasn't the place because I was a young man at that time. I was going to date and all that.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And people talked about me in the town. Everybody knew me. I was in the newspaper.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes. In fact, you might have a picture of me and my brother.

segments.question: Really? In the newspaper at the time?
segments.answer: Paterson Evening News.

segments.question: Paterson Evening News.
segments.answer: Yes. You probably have a picture of it.

segments.question: Well, if I can look online, I might just find one. You never know.
segments.answer: I think I gave it to you guys.

segments.question: I'll take a look. I'll take a look in your folder. I don't remember seeing one but I'll take a look.
segments.answer: If not, I'll send you a copy also.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 88
segments.answer: So --

segments.question: But I had a question.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: I know I'm interrupting but I had a question.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And it was when you were still back in 1945 --
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- before you come to the United States.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: When you turned 18, tell me, what kind of a person were you? I mean, most 18-year- olds today are still -- you can't call them kids anymore but they're not yet adults and yet you had seen so much. You had been through so much. How do you describe the person who turned 18 years old in 1945?
segments.answer: I think you grow up fast. I had a responsibility to my brother.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And he was really little, skinny and little.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So if because of the war, he's that little, the nourishment --

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: -- or by genes, but he didn't grow too tall.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 89
segments.answer: And, you know, I wanted him to go to school. He was smart. And I would be going to work, you know, and just keep him in school.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: It turn out that this man came to pick him up.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And offered to give him an education. And, you know, and he went to Los Banos, California. You know, I wasn't very happy in New Jersey because I was of age but I was trying to date.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And everybody knew me in town. Wherever I went, everybody knew me. Wherever I'd go --

segments.question: So you didn't have much privacy.
segments.answer: -- the whole town knew.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I got to ajob. I worked for a man who was from Belgium. And one of the reasons he hired me, because I spoke French. So, you know, I had a job for a while and I decided New Jersey, Paterson, New Jersey, is not going to be for me because the people, everybody knew me in town. And I couldn't go out with anybody because everybody knew it.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So I had to behave.

segments.question: No privacy at all. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 90
segments.answer: I had to behave.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So I left New Jersey and went to California. I had $50 in my pocket. I bought a ticket.

segments.question: How did you get there?

segments.answer: So from Blechhammer we walked. And every second night or every night, if I remember right, they took us to a farm. And we slept outside in the barns, where they had the cows and the pigs, and you know, the prisoners went there to sleep.

They were aiming at the guards, primarily, and they carried guns, machine guns and rifles and so on to watch the prisoners. And we walked. Probably every night Interview with Jacques Ribons 112 we stopped. We slept outside in the snow. And on a Sunday, we wound up in a barn with the cows and pigs.

segments.question: How were you dressed?
segments.answer: In -- very skimpy, in the prisoners' uniforms that we wore. Myself, personally, I had a -- I happened to have a sweater somehow. I don't remember how I got it. And I wore that sweater. And I also wore bags, you know, the empty bags of cement as protection to keep warm.

segments.question: And you would wear that under the uniform?
segments.answer: Oh, yes. Oh, yes.

segments.question: And what kind of footwear did you have?
segments.answer: Myself, I had a pair of boots somehow I got, and there were no soles on them.

segments.question: Oh, my.
segments.answer: So you know, they were very skimpy. It was actually -- you know, we got all wet. My feet got all wet. And well, I didn't have any shoes. So I wrapped, you know, some of the stuff, my feet in cloth, that I could find or whatever I could get, you know, so my feet wouldn't freeze.

segments.question: So when you were walking along the side of the road, and it was January, and there was the machine gunning from the Soviets, and the Germans as well, were there snow drifts? Was it loud? Was it icy?
segments.answer: No. We actually walked not on the outside of the road, because it was impossible to walk, but we walked on the main road to the side.

segments.question: Isee. Interview with Jacques Ribons 113
segments.answer: And you know, on one side of the street. And as we were walking, the Russians, I don't know if willingly or not, the machine gun, primarily, they tried to machine gun the guards.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And of course, the guards moved in among the prisoners. So you know, I guess they must have hit some prisoners.

segments.question: Isee. So the guards would realize this, and then they would intermingle with the prisoners?
segments.answer: With the prisoners, correct.

segments.question: Isee. And by that point, were there a lot of German guards, or was it few and far between?
segments.answer: No, it was a lot of guards. Again, they carried machine guns. However, you know, the roads were full of people going west, because the Russians were right behind us. So we could hear rifle shots from time to time. So they were very, very close behind us.

segments.question: So you were about to talk about one Sunday you ended up someplace.
segments.answer: One Sunday, we ended up in a barn. I don't know where that was. And they gave us coffee. And they were shooting, practicing, I guess, either that or shooting at the legs of the prisoners. So of course, they fell, and us, we left them there.

segments.question: Who was doing the shooting?
segments.answer: The Germans.

segments.question: The Germans were shooting at the legs of the prisoners?
segments.answer: Right. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 114

segments.question: As you were drinking coffee?
segments.answer: Well, we were getting coffee from that big -- what do you call it -- pot, and they were giving the prisoners coffee. Well, the prisoners did, but the Germans are the ones that allowed that to happen, the coffee pot.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And as we got the coffee, they were shooting at the legs of the prisoners.

segments.question: Oh, my.
segments.answer: So when that happened, of course, they fell. They couldn't stand up.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: And we had to leave them behind. And I am sure -- I personally didn't see it, but I'm sure they killed them after they left.

segments.question: Yeah. Yeah. Did people die as they were marching?
segments.answer: Oh, yes, many, many people. They were actually froze to death. We had to sleep in the snow. Occasionally, on a Sunday -- we walked about three Sundays, and I was able, with my brother and some other kids, get into a barn with the cows and the pigs, you know, and keep warm, you know.

segments.question: So you were walking for at least three Sundays?
segments.answer: I believe it was three Sundays.

segments.question: So that would mean at least two weeks, maybe more?
segments.answer: Three weeks.

segments.question: Three weeks?
segments.answer: About two to three weeks. And again, I don't know how many prisoners died during Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 115 that march.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I mean, it must have been an enormous amount of prisoners that passed on. I try to -- I'm sorry.

segments.question: No, I was going to say, it's the kind of stamina you would need in order to survive that would be very high, and some people just couldn't hold out.
segments.answer: That's correct. We fought for our lives, literally.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I was fortunate. I was able to make it. I tried to help a man that I knew in prison. He was from France. And his name was Ribak.

segments.question: Ribak?
segments.answer: R-I-B-A-C or B-A-K. I don't know how he spelled it.

segments.question: R-I-C --
segments.answer: No, no. R -- Ribak.

segments.question: Oh, R-I-B-A-C-K?
segments.answer: R-I-B, yes. And I helped him as much as I could, and then I finally gave up. I couldn't do it any longer, and --

segments.question: In what way were you trying to help him; by helping him walk?
segments.answer: By helping him walk. Yes, by helping him walk. I mean, I knew him in prison. We occasionally worked side by side, you know, so.

segments.question: Did anybody try to escape?
segments.answer: Probably. I didn't have the stamina. I wouldn't know where to go. Interview with Jacques Ribons 116

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: You know.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: We were in Germany at the time, so.

segments.question: Were there civilians on the road, too? I'm sorry I interrupted.
segments.answer: Oh, yes, there were civilians. There were people with push carts and their belongings. There were all kinds of people that walked, because they were trying to avoid the Russians, you know, particularly if they were Germans, you know.

segments.question: It sounds like chaos.
segments.answer: Yes, it was, absolutely. And we had Russian prisoners, and you know, all kinds of prisoners walked alongside of us. The road wasn't big enough for all of these people that walked, including the German Army.

segments.question: Tell me this, how many lanes did it have, or at least the main roads you were on? Were they single lanes, one in each direction, or were they wider than that?
segments.answer: I believe they were wider than that. I'm not sure, you know. Again, we were fighting for our lives. We didn't pay attention too much of what was going on around us, except, you know, we tried to hide from the bullets.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: You know, and we didn't know they were Russian planes until they came down real low.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So it was chaos, absolutely chaos. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 117

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And it was a 250-mile stretch. And I took my daughter and my son and my grandson on that stretch from Blechhammer to Gross-Rosen in a van.

segments.question: Oh, my gosh.
segments.answer: Just recently about a year ago.

segments.question: So that would be like in 2013?
segments.answer: Yes. Yes.

segments.question: So you redid the whole death march walk?
segments.answer: The whole trip, yes, the whole trip. From my hometown where I was born to the trip, all the way to Gross-Rosen and from Gross-Rosen to Buchenwald.

segments.question: So tell me, the 250 miles, does that go from your hometown to Buchenwald, or does that go just from Blechhammer’?
segments.answer: From Blechhammer to Gross-Rosen was about a 250-mile stretch. At least, I didn't know. My daughter told me that it was that distance.

segments.question: Ofcourse. I mean, at that time, how would you know. It took you three weeks or so at that time. How long did it take by van when you went?
segments.answer: By van, I don't know, about eight hours, ten hours. I'm not sure. I didn't even think of paying attention to that, you know.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I drove with my daughter, my grandson and my son.

segments.question: Did any of it look familiar to you, the road, when you went on it again?
segments.answer: No, no, no. It was totally changed, because they -- first of all, you know, with so Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 118 much chaos, you didn't even pay attention to anything, except, you know, you try to survive. You know, the food was very scarce. I was in one of the areas where you ate in one of the farms that we walked in. I saw a house, people, that the farmer, I guess, lived in. And I run to the farmer, knocked on their door asking for food, for bread. And the commander, so to speak, the person in charge of the prisoners, he said, What are you doing here, in German. And I said, I would like to have something to eat. So that young woman -- it was a young woman. He said, he says, you can give him bread, provided that you sleep with me tonight.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: So she says okay. And she gave me a loaf of bread. And when I went out, I got hit over my back with a cane. And I went to my brother, and I gave him half of the bread. We ate that just one night, you know.

segments.question: Oh, my gosh. What a horrible -- what a horrible situation and how cruel, how absolutely cruel.
segments.answer: It's much crueler than anybody can even anticipate.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah. What human beings will do in order to kill the humanity in others.
segments.answer: Well, I would imagine, you know, it happens all over, even today.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So the cruelest animal on earth is the human being.

segments.question: Unfortunately. Unfortunately.
segments.answer: So anyhow, then we got to Gross-Rosen. We were there for several days. We were packed like sardines. And we had just a bowl of soup during the day. And I don't Interview with Jacques Ribons 119 remember whether we got bread or not. We were there for almost about a week. And that was Gross-Rosen. And Gross-Rosen was very secluded, because they had -- they were mining marble in that area. So the people on the outside couldn't see what was going on there in that -- in Gross-Rosen. And you know, after five days or so, a week maybe, maybe longer, they loaded up -- they loaded us up on the freight trains. They were going and taking the marble to market, I guess. And they loaded up the prisoners on these open freight trains, and they took us. We didn't know where we were going, and with guards on them. Each car had two guards with machine guns or regular guns. I'm not sure what. At that time, I wasn't really familiar with the weapons.

segments.question: Yeah. Just that they can kill.
segments.answer: Right. So they -- when they loaded us up, we were on the way. And we got all the way to Weimar where we were bombed. I think the allied's air force made a mistake and didn't know who it was, because they did see guards watching these things, you know, and they bombed the train. A lot of Germans, the guards, including the prisoners, were killed, a lot of them.

segments.question: Yeah. And this was allied bombing?
segments.answer: This was allied bombing. I don't know what air force that was there.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But primarily, I think the U.S. Air Force was in that area, or the U.S. Army was in that area, you know, so.

segments.question: Did you ever make it then to Buchenwald —
segments.answer: Yes. Interview with Jacques Ribons 120

segments.question: -- or just to Weimar?
segments.answer: No, we made it into Buchenwald. They took us to Buchenwald, and I --

segments.question: Excuse me. Can I interrupt you for a minute.
segments.answer: Sure.

segments.question: Did the train go until Weimar, the Town of Weimar, or did it go up to the camp at Buchenwald?
segments.answer: To my knowledge, the railroad into Buchenwald, the railroad tracks, to my knowledge, if I remember right, were bombed out. So they took us by truck.

segments.question: Isee. I see.
segments.answer: Into Buchenwald. It was not all that far.

segments.question: No, no. It isn't that far.
segments.answer: So in fact, we used to walk it after the war. Because Buchenwald 1s in the mountains, and this is below the mountain. So from there, we were there, I don't know, from January until April.

segments.question: So you were in Buchenwald for all that time?
segments.answer: Oh, yes, and we were in what is called a children's barracks. It had three -- I think they had three or four barracks where they kept just children. And I guess, there was a whole story behind it, because the -- also Germans, since the 1930s, were -- they were prisoners.

segments.question: Yes. In Buchenwald, it had had a lot of German political prisoners.
segments.answer: Right. So they sort of protected, to my knowledge, the kids. And at the time that they tried to take the kids out, we went to this appellplatz, and you know, we all lined up. Interview with Jacques Ribons 121 And then they took us back to the barracks. What happened in the interim, I don't know. I guess they had -- they had, within the prison, you know, people that carried guns. In fact, outside of Buchenwald, there was an ammunition factory.

segments.question: Now, I'm a little confused at this point. When you were in Buchenwald from January to April, --
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: -- who was in control?
segments.answer: Well, the Germans were in control. However, there also, since the factory where most of the German prisoners worked, and the other prisoners, I don't know which one of the prisoners they kept work in the ammunition factory, they smuggled in a lot of arms, the Germans.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And to my knowledge, they had Germans with guns roaming the prison. So I guess, the Germans feared a lot that the prisoners, whether it was the Germans or Russian prisoners, I don't know, but I know there were Germans.

segments.question: Okay. But when you are saying Germans, are you talking about German political prisoners or --
segments.answer: German political prisoners that smuggled in arms.

segments.question: Oh, I see what you are saying. They were working in the ammunitions factory.
segments.answer: Inthe ammunitions factory.

segments.question: They were smuggling in some arms that were kept secret from the authorities?
segments.answer: Absolutely, yes. Interview with Jacques Ribons 122

segments.question: And yet, they would patrol the place with those arms; is that correct?
segments.answer: Not patrol, but they watched. As soon as the Germans left, they took over.

segments.question: Isee. As soon as the regular Nazi, you know, they left, then these political prisoners
segments.answer: Yes, these political prisoners came out and tried to help -- they were not just Germans. They were all kinds of prisoners. There were Swedes, and they had Danes. I don't know where -- the Danes I can understand, but I don't understand the Swedes, how they got there.

segments.question: Yeah, because they are supposed to be neutral.
segments.answer: Right. I don't know how they got there, but they had them there. So and the reason I know that to be a fact is because I was hospitalized. I had extreme diarrhea that they -- I begged them to take me away already. I couldn't take it anymore.

segments.question: I remember that part in our conversation before, yes.
segments.answer: Right. So --

segments.question: And what was -- what did you do and your brother when you were there? Were you also put to work or --
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: -- or not?
segments.answer: No. In Buchenwald, we didn't work.

segments.question: Isee.
segments.answer: At least the time, the period of time that I was there.

segments.question: Isee. Okay. Interview with Jacques Ribons 123
segments.answer: You know, there were deaths all over. People cut out the innards of the dead and ate, you know. This is the kind of stuff that I saw. It was a matter of either dying or doing that, so.

segments.question: What about, when you say that the Nazi authorities left and the political prisoners took over, could you say that they liberated -- the German political prisoners liberated the camp, or was it another army that did it?
segments.answer: No, no. I think it was -- I can't think of the general's name that came in. Let me kind of put a little emphasis on the whole situation, the whole picture there.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: They had a -- if I can remember the town -- Erfurt.

segments.question: Erfurt, yes, is near there.
segments.answer: It was in the mountains, across the mountains. You could see from Buchenwald all the way into the mountains of Erfurt. They had a battle going on in Erfurt. At night, we used to see the cannons going off, the artillery going off at night from Erfurt, because it lit up. So the general who was the tank commander, and I can't remember his name. My memory 1s not like it used to be.

segments.question: That's easy to find out though. We can look it up, you know, who that would have been.
segments.answer: Well, he got killed in Germany in a car crash or something. I'm not sure how he died, the general.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: He was in charge of the tank unit that came into Buchenwald. Interview with Jacques Ribons 124

segments.question: And did you see then American soldiers?
segments.answer: Yes. There was just a tank came in with a couple -- they opened the turret, and they peaked out. And the Germans were already gone. They jumped off the guard towers, and the prisoners were chasing them. You know, so they caught some. You know, it was all chaos, you know.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: They killed some, you know, and they brought some back to prison. So they -- the Germans were gone.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: The army came in and -- the American Army came in, and of course, they start giving us food, you know, rations and stuff like that. And then organizations came in from western Europe that fed us after a while. So but as a whole, Erfurt, they were there for about a week or maybe more. They were shooting at the Germans across the mountains, and you could see it. At night, you could see it.

segments.question: So when they finally came into the -- into Buchenwald itself, the tank and with the solders, --
segments.answer: The tank, yeah, with the people in it, opened the turret and looked out.

segments.question: And did they get out?
segments.answer: You know, I don't recall that.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don't recall if they got out or were in the tanks.

segments.question: Where were you when you saw this? Interview with Jacques Ribons 125
segments.answer: We kind of roamed around, because there was nobody there to keep us anywhere, you know, because the Germans were already gone. I saw the Germans -- you know, I used to sleep on the top bunk. It was three high.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And the top bunk, I could look out the window. You know, what it is was glass, and when I got the window in a certain position, we could see the main road.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Right. So they -- because we were on top of a mountain.

segments.question: That's right. It was high up.
segments.answer: Right. So we looked in there, and I saw the tanks, the Germans running and Germans jumping off the towers. And it was just like a movie scene of some sort. So this 1s what I saw through that window. And I was kind of -- you know, because they were shooting into the barracks. So we got to the ground on the floor, and we just waited it out, you know.

segments.question: Were there any revenge killings?
segments.answer: Yes. They had, some of the people, I don't know what rank they were, what capacity they were, the Germans, they took them in to where they held the prisoners, the Buchenwald prisoners, you know, that they tortured them there. And they took the Germans, and they gave us two hours for people to go in and beat them up.

segments.question: Yeah. Yeah.
segments.answer: So--

segments.question: And things took place then, huh? Interview with Jacques Ribons 126
segments.answer: Well, you know, you punch the guy. How much revenge can you take, you know, SO.

segments.question: Yeah. What did I want to ask you? Now, there is a famous photograph of, I believe itis Eisenhower. I'm not exactly sure. But when he comes and he sees what has happened at Buchenwald, he is so appalled that he orders the townspeople of Weimar to come and be forced to look at --
segments.answer: Right.

data: -- what was going on in the camp.
Correct. Q. Were you still there when that happened?
Yeah. That was in the beginning, you know, because we were there several weeks after.

segments.question: Okay. Can you tell me about that?
segments.answer: About that, I cannot tell you very much. But you know, because first of all, the army kept away the prisoners from these people that they brought in.

segments.question: Oh, so you saw them at a distance?
segments.answer: We saw them in the distance. We couldn't get so close to them, because of the fact that, you know, revenge would have taken place. And in the U.S., don't take revenge on other people, you know, even, you know, they come into a town, and they don't kill other people.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Either they keep them prisoners or whatever. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 127

segments.question: So in other words, the reason why the prisoners were kept away from the townspeople was because to prevent any kind of violence happening?
segments.answer: Well, you couldn't help some violence.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Because the prison -- the wires were all torn down. You could go out through the wires anywhere you wanted to go. I used to go to the villages and ask for things to eat, you know, in the beginning.

segments.question: And did they give them to you?
segments.answer: Oh, yes. Oh, yes. I think they had so much fear in them, that 1t was beyond belief. You know, a guy nearby Buchenwald was a mayor of this particular town. He was made mayor right after the Germans moved away and the Allieds came in, the Allied Forces. I don't know who installed him as mayor, but he was the mayor. I walked into the mayor's house, and I asked him, I would like to have a bike. He says, no problem. He gave me an address, and I went up there and tried to get the bike. And of course, the bikes were all hidden. You couldn't find them. So you know, the idea is that the -- the reason I'm saying that, that the Germans had so much fear of being beaten up or being killed. And in fact, some of them were.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: By the Russian prisoners, you know, the ones that were older, not the youngsters, you know.

segments.question: Finish the story about the bike. Did you finally get a bike?
segments.answer: No. They didn't have it. It was all empty. Interview with Jacques Ribons 128

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: All the barns were empty. Everything was empty. You know, so I didn't get a bike.

segments.question: So but it means that by the time that the Americans got -- they were entrenched there, you were able to move out of the camp?
segments.answer: Oh, absolutely. Somehow or another, we got right through the fence. The fence was torn apart, and we just walked out. And we went to the nearby towns. I went a couple of times to Weimar.

segments.question: What was it like? Did you still wear your prisoner's uniform?
segments.answer: We didn't have anything else, really. Just a prisoner's uniform.

segments.question: How did people behave?
segments.answer: Fear.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Some of them were beaten up by others, by the prisoners. So, you know, I was a kid incapable of doing anything, too weak.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: SO.

segments.question: But you saw it in their eyes?
segments.answer: Oh, yes. I saw it, saw them being beaten up, and they were beaten up when they brought the Germans in. I don't know whether it was soldiers or civilians that were brought in, and kept them where they used to torture the prisoners. They kept them there. And they used to let them in at, let's say, 3:00 in the afternoon for a half hour to beat the hell out of them, you know. But you know. Interview with Jacques Ribons 129

data: But were these civilians that were brought in there? A. Yes, civilians. I don't know what capacity, or if they were soldiers, they also were, you know, in probably civilian uniforms. I have no idea.

segments.question: But what I'm trying to get at is, they weren't former guards that you could recognize?
segments.answer: No. No.

segments.question: Okay. The reason they were brought in is because they happened to be German, not because they happened to have been a particularly cruel guard?
segments.answer: They had some too.

segments.question: Oh, yeah. I'm sure.
segments.answer: But they watched how much beating they could get, you know. They wouldn't allow, even though that person had seen about 19 Germans being shot, you know, soldiers.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And I couldn't tell you who shot them. I know they wore military uniforms, but whether there were civilians in the uniforms or American or any other nationality that shot him, you know, so.

segments.question: And how old were you at this point?
segments.answer: Iwas born in 1927. This was '45.

segments.question: You were 18 years old when you were seeing this?
segments.answer: Yes. You know, we were used to seeing all kinds of stuff.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Ihave seen dogs chasing the prisoners and eat them up alive, you know, kill them Interview with Jacques Ribons 130 and eat them. You know, it was not something -- or people being hung, for whatever reason that they found, you know. So it was not something that --

segments.question: It's not new to you, in other words?
segments.answer: -- I hadn't seen before. It wasn't new.

segments.question: It wasn't new to you?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: It was already --
segments.answer: I, myself, were under a gun once or twice, you know, but I -- they let me go.

segments.question: You mean you were under threat of being shot?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And this was where?
segments.answer: This was still in the ghetto.

segments.question: Isee. Oh, Iremember. I remember. Yeah, you had told me about that. How long did you stay at Buchenwald after the Americans arrived?
segments.answer: It wasn't really that long. There was a -- you know, I didn't know, because I didn't -- there was a rabbi, I suppose. He was an American chaplain that worked on taking the kids out of Buchenwald. And I guess, each government, to my knowledge, I found out later, let in so many kids. And some kids, I understand, went to Cuba. Some kids went to England. Some went to Switzerland, and they went to France, they went to Belgium. It depended on the government how many kids they would allow in, into the country.

segments.question: Isee. And so you were amongst that group?
segments.answer: I was amongst that group that went to France. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 131

segments.question: And how long did you stay there? Where did they take you?
segments.answer: They took us, if I -- if my memory 1s right, to a home that the Rothschild family owned.

segments.question: That the Rothschild family owned?
segments.answer: And they gave the home, I guess, to use for the kids for the summer. I don't know. They had their hires in France to take care of all the kids. To what capacity, I have no idea. They gave us a home. They gave us food. They gave us schooling, you know.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: They sent us to school, you know. So it was a variety of things, and I don't know who was what.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: You know, like for instance, my friend, Elie Wiesel, look what happened to him. He went to the Sorbonne in Paris.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: You know, the guy that was also his friend, my hometown friend, a fellow by the name of Gallenstein (ph.), he went also to the Sorbonne, because they were geniuses. They were geniuses, these guys. And I don't know who else. And they sent them to trade schools, and they sent them to different things. I came to the United States early enough, you know, right past -- it wasn't that long after that, about a year, year and a half maybe.

segments.question: Do you remember the date that you came to the U.S.?
segments.answer: The date exactly --

segments.question: Or the month? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Jacques Ribons 132
segments.answer: Yes, I do, but I have it written down.

segments.question: It's okay. I'm just curious.
segments.answer: Yes, Ido have it. I have it written down. I used to know, but I don't know now.

segments.question: Yeah. Did you sail into New York?
segments.answer: At the moment, I cannot remember.

segments.question: That's okay. Did you sail into New York or some other port?
segments.answer: No, we came -- we went to -- from France, they took us to Sweden. We came from Sweden across the SS Gripsholm, which used to be a cruise ship in War World II. It was reconverted into a passenger ship. And they brought us into New York. There was a lot of other people.
